intro: Brassica repanda subsp. almeriensis, commonly known as the Almeria mustard, is a rare and endemic plant species native to southern Spain. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid soils, showcasing adaptations to harsh Mediterranean climates. Its leaves are lobed and often covered in a fine pubescence, while its flowers range in color from yellow to pale orange. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
